Award.AwardTitle: NSF-AFOSR Joint Workshop on Mechanics-Based Design of Intelligent Material Systems by Multimaterial Additive Manufacturing; Melbourne, Australia; August 15, 2019

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides financial support for the workshop entitled NSF-AFOSR Joint Workshop on Mechanics-Based Design of Intelligent Material Systems by Multimaterial Additive Manufacturing, to be held on August 15, 2019, in Melbourne, Australia, during the 22nd International Conference on Composite Materials 2019. Recent advances in additive manufacturing technologies have drastically changed the perception of how multifunctional composites and structures are designed and fabricated. The emergence of multimaterial 3D printing--precise placement of dissimilar materials in space--has opened unprecedented opportunities up for creating new types of composites. While tremendous research possibilities exist, center to these opportunities is mechanics, which is not only critical in understanding fundamental engineering issues, such as interface properties and reliability, but also drives innovative design through mechanical behavior, such as mismatch of strains and nonlinear thermomechanics. The objective of this workshop is to review the recent progress in the mechanics-based design of intelligent material systems by multimaterial additive manufacturing and to identify new directions and opportunities. Funding from this grant will support travel costs for 13 invited speakers to attend the workshop and present their work, and two graduate students for organizing the workshop as well as the production of a report.

In this one-day workshop, 13 invited leading experts in mechanics of multifunctional materials as well as additive manufacturing from across academia, government, and industry will discuss present and future challenges and opportunities related to the mechanics-based design of intelligent material systems by multimaterial additive manufacturing. The workshop will be comprised of three sessions in a single technical track with each session covering a different topic and having two 25-min presentations, three 5-min presentations, and one 30-minute discussion period. With each session covering a different topic and allowing plenty of discussion time, this unique format is intended to foster discussions around the most important technical challenges in each topic and opportunities for future research. This workshop will also feature a final one-hour panel discussion that will integrate the topics and discussions from the three sessions. The outcome of these presentations and discussions will be documented in a final report and will be widely disseminated across academia, government, and industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF-AFOSR Joint Workshop on Mechanics-Based Design of Intelligent Material Systems by Multi-Material Additive Manufacturing workshop has two goals: 1) identifying the state of the art and challenges by reviewing the recent progress in mechanics-based design of intelligent material systems by multimaterial AM and 2) providing recommendations for new directions and opportunities. The recommendations are intended to guide the mechanics of materials communities, as well as the materials, design, and manufacturing communities to focus on specific areas that best suit their discipline research as well as educate the requisite workforce.

Intelligent material systems refer to materials that can sense and respond to internal or external changes. They are typically achieved by integrating different functions into one system. Such an integration imposes significant challenges for mechanics, materials, design, and fabrication. Recent advances in additive manufacturing (AM) technologies have drastically changed how we design and fabricate intelligent material systems. In particular, the emergence of multimaterial 3D printing has opened up unprecedented opportunities to create new types of intelligent material systems. While a large number of research topics exist, mechanics not only plays a critical role in understanding fundamental problems, such as process-structure-property relationship, mechanical and multiphyiscal behaviors, interface properties, reliability, etc., but also guides innovative designs by fundamental principles in mechanics. This workshop brought together researchers from academia, national labs, and industry with expertise in mechanics, materials, design, and AM to review the recent progress in mechanics-based design of intelligent material systems by multimaterial AM and to identify new opportunities. Since the majority of participants work on polymers, the discussions were primarily polymer-related.

The daylong workshop in Melbourne, Australia on August 15, 2019, during the 22nd International Conference on Composite Materials (ICCM22) gathered more than 30 participants, including 12 invited speakers from academia, industry, and national labs with the expertise in mechanics, materials, design, and manufacturing, to discuss the state of the art, challenges, and opportunities for future research. Through presentations and facilitated discussions, a list of challenges, including both cultural and scientific challenges, were identified, as summarized below.

Challenges

A. New materials and mechanics 

  • Difficulty in bringing together multiple material streams with different rheological behaviors or melting points
  • Difficulty in controlling the chemistry to obtain multiple properties from a single resin
  • Deficiency of the properties of existing materials
  • Uncertainties due to the interfaces between dissimilar materials and material joining
  • Complexity in modeling of 3D printed materials
  • Lack of material characterization standards

B. New AM methods enable new multifunctional materials

  • Limited number of high-speed multimaterial AM methods
  • No or very few AM methods that can printing different classes of materials
  • Limited efforts to model the AM process
  • Limited knowledge about defect formation mechanisms and lack of part inspection
  • Lack of methods for process monitoring
  • New born-qualified parts
  • Tradeoff between resolution, size, and print speed

C. Design and analysis

  • Unexpected failure of the optimized parts
  • Including uncertainties in the optimization

D. Cultural challenges

  • Work end-to-end in a collaborative environment and information sharing
  • Barriers due to segregation among different disciplines
  • The trial-and-error-based R&D process
  • Academic research and industry applications
  • IP policy

The challenges present also many opportunities. Based on the identified challenges, several recommendations were made to address both scientific as well as cultural challenges.

Recommendations

A. Cultural recommendations

  • Information sharing
  • Multidisciplinary group efforts
  • Collaboration with industrial stakeholders
  • IP policy guided by funding agencies

B. Scientific area recommendations

  • Simulation platform for AM process
  • Defects and their formation mechanisms
  • Constitutive modeling of 3D printed materials considering printing and postprocessing
  • Interfacial properties
  • Expanding material sets available for AM
  • High throughput characterization
  • Design with uncertainties
  • Integrated design, manufacturing, quantification, and verification
  • Scale-up AM

 


Last Modified: 04/13/2020
Modified by: Hang (Jerry) Qi
